Thanks Ken for your answer. It makes sense to use it for more complex tas=
ks. 

Btw I think the BEV could be relatively easily extended to higher dim=
ensions (e.g. from a 3d space to another 3d space), though I can't think of=
 any practical reason to do this. Just food for thought...


--- In neat@ya=
hoogroups.com, "Ken" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> 
> 
> Vassilis, we could in =
fact insert a hidden layer (i.e. a new "slice") into the state-space sandwi=
ch in Keepaway.  It is probably true that there are some more complex behav=
iors that could be learned that way than with the current setup.  However, =
the cost would be slower learning and since the current setup is sufficient=
 for the Keepaway task, it may not be really important for that task.  Howe=
ver, if the task was made more complex, it could become necessary.
> 
> Not=
e that even if the substrate was not allowed to evolve, we could still inse=
rt the hidden layer at a fixed resolution.  We could also allow the hidden =
layer node placement to evolve as well.  It's difficult to say the impact o=
f that idea on this domain since the evolvable substrate (ES-HyperNEAT) is =
such a new approach, but I would guess again that the current task setup wo=
uld not really need it, though it might be useful as it gets more complex.
=
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "v.vassiliades" <vassilisvas@> w=
rote:
> >
> > Hi all and Happy Easter,
> > 
> > 
> > I liked the ideas in y=
our new papers:
> > - Evolving the Placement and Density of Neurons in the =
HyperNEAT Substrate
> > - Transfer Learning through Indirect Encodng
> > 
>=
 > I was wondering whether you had any thoughts about combining them. More =
specifically, by allowing hidden nodes inside the "state-space sandwich" co=
nfiguration. 
> > 
> > Do you think it makes sense to have hidden nodes bet=
ween the input and output sheets of neurons?
> > 
> > 
> > Thanks,
> > 
> >=
 Vassilis
> >
>
